title: Solana proposes network upgrade changes following recent outage - CryptoSlate
content:
Solana co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko said plans are in place to improve network reliability.

The Solana network suffered a significant outage on Feb. 25, leading to downtime that lasted close to 20 hours. It was the first interruption of service to occur this year. However, 2022 saw 11 major outages and 3 minor ones – cementing a reputation for poor network reliability.

Yakovenko said last week’s outage was related to the 1.14 network update, which was intended to bring speed and scale improvements.

“Up to the 1.14 release, core engineers were working to fix live problems that were impacting the network’s speed and usability. These issues included invalid gas metering, lack of flow control for transactions, lack of fee markets, spiraling ram, storage and restart overhead.”

However, the rollout of the 1.14 update triggered significant network degradation, the cause of which is unknown at this time. An investigation to determine the root cause is still ongoing.

Solana focused on network stability

Addressing the issue will focus on improving the software release process for updates. This will involve using external developers and auditors to hunt for bugs and exploits.

Other changes include forming an adversarial team to “build additional hooks and instrumentation into the validator code” for more thorough testing. Also, looking into simpler, more efficient network restart procedures.

“Nodes should be automatically discovering the latest optimistically confirmed slot and sharing the ledger with each other if it is missing.”

Yakovenko said over the past 12 months, Solana was already working on improving network stability through various initiatives, including building a second validator client, better tooling, upgrading the network communication protocol to “QUIC,” and improvements to the RPC infrastructure.

Mentioned in this article

title: Solana, Other Altcoins and Crypto Trends To Watch in 2023 - Yahoo Finance
content:
Dennis Diatel Photography / Getty Images

The crypto market has been battered since 2022, and it has been a rollercoaster for several assets. Implosions, fears of contagion and ensuing confusion have put an enormous strain on several of them.

The Future of Finances: Gen Z & How They Relate to Money

See: 3 Things You Must Do When Your Savings Reach $50,000

Yet, while it’s too early to tell whether it has recovered, crypto seems off to a better start in 2023. Take, for example, the Solana blockchain and its native coin (SOL).

Solana’s ‘Rocky Six Months’

Following the collapse of FTX — with which Solana was entangled — Solana’s asset value was one of the most impacted. Its market capitalization dropped by 70%, according to a Messari report.

Live Richer Podcast: How To Leverage Your Investments

Yet, over just the past two weeks, SOL has rebounded and was up 8.1% as of Feb. 27, according to CoinGecko, hovering around $24. It is up a whopping 133% year to date, according to CoinDesk data. On the other hand, it is also down 91% from its Nov. 6, 2021, all-time-high of $259.96, according to CoinGecko.

“Solana has had a rocky six months, from its association with Sam Bankman-Fried to this recent forking incident,” said Christopher Alexander, chief communications officer of Liberty Blockchain. “The market clearly believes in Solana’s long-term vision. If you believe in coins that are building infrastructure like Ethereum, it makes sense to support that chain.”

In terms of the forking incident that made the asset’s price drop, Alexander attributes it to the fact that Solana prefers to move fast and that comes at a price, while Bitcoin and Ethereum have a strategy to proceed with caution.

“Speed allows innovation that means Solana leaps ahead of its competition in the Layer 1 [blockchain] space,” he said. “The downside is that they can fail or succeed spectacularly and the timing of something breaking now is unfortunate for them.”

Other Coins and Trends To Watch

Experts say there are a few other assets and trends worth watching this year, each for different reasons — even though everyone is proceeding with extreme caution.

According to Hayden Hughes, co-founder and CEO of Alpha Impact, Polygon (MATIC) is one of them. It has been warmly received by the investor community, notably on the heels of announcements by Instagram and JPMorgan that they’ll be using the blockchain for settlement and trading of digital assets.

Another one to watch, according to Hughes, is UNI.

“The Uniswap token shares its name with the largest decentralized exchange on the market,” Hughes said. “Although the token is not used directly in Uniswap’s ecosystem, this is rumored to be changing. The team is focused on building utility for the token.”

Story continues

Another Focus: Liquid Staking Derivatives

Another area of interest according to several experts, is liquid staking derivatives (LSDs). Lido (LDO), he said, is the largest of the so-called LSDs, which allows users to deposit locked assets, with the view of bringing liquidity to the assets that previously were not interchangeable.

Matt Maximo, research analyst at Grayscale, noted that he too sees LSDs as an area of interest this year. Lido’s stETH offers investors a way to gain exposure to Ethereum (ETH) and staking yield, while also being compatible with DeFi.

“For many users, investors and traders, it may be more advantageous to hold the LSD derivative of Ethereum,” Maximo said, “as it provides liquid exposure to ETH and staking yield, instead of just holding ETH or locking it up in a validator.”

With the Shanghai hardfork, Ethereum’s next upgrade, expected in the next few weeks, LSDs have performed extremely well this year. The largest tokens — such as FXS, RPL, LDO — have gained more than 125%.

“I expect this trend to continue long term into and beyond the Shanghai hard fork,” Maximo said. “Granted, there may be some short-term volatility with ETH unlocks and macro headwinds.”

Layer 2, RWA and More

Additional areas of interest for 2023 include significant growth in Layer 2 scaling solutions, which was reaffirmed by the recent launch of Coinbase’s L2 solution “Base.”

Finally, Maximo said real world asset (RWA) tokenization on the blockchain is a process that may seem gradual and unassuming, but once it reaches a critical mass, it is bound to surprise and captivate everyone with its immense growth and impact.

“Stablecoins serve as a notable illustration of the potential value of tokenized RWAs within the crypto landscape,” he said. “Beyond stablecoins, other RWAs such as bonds, Treasury bills, real estate, commodities and more can also be tokenized and transacted on a decentralized network.”

In addition, crypto experts such as Dara Albright note the emergence of “next-gen self-sustainable altcoins in the Participate-2-Earn space that enables individuals to be compensated for their participation in their routine activities such as learning, exercising, binge-watching.”

Albright, an expert with crypto marketplace Earnity and host of the Decent Millionaire podcast, pointed out Health Hero, a Health-2-Earn company that incentivizes users for staying healthy.

“Not only because it possesses a long-term, supportable pricing support system for its token that taps into $15 billion of healthcare-related real-world assets,” Albright said, “but because of the healthcare benefits it could bring about on a macro level.”

Focus on Utility

All in all, while the crypto space seems to be slowly regaining ground following the depths of the seemingly never-ending crypto winter, lessons from the FTX bust have been learned and experts are proceeding with caution about what the future holds.

Transparency, viability and utility are taking precedence over short-lived, hyper-hyped trends.

As Calanthia Mei, co-founder of Masa Finance, noted, trends are fueled by the narratives that drive them; and, like the seasons, they are constantly changing.

“We’ve seen some absolutely wild trends historically,” Mei said. “Flashback to DeFi summer, where coins named after food which could be yield-farmed were all the rage. To meme coin madness, where coins named after every breed of dog imaginable were skyrocketing.

“While these trends were fun, fast-paced and extremely volatile,” Mei added, “we see this year as a new chapter for crypto and a turning point for the industry. As investors separate the signal from the noise, we see a focus on real utility, scalability, network adoption and value being key to the next cycle.”

The sentiment is also echoed by Arie Trouw, co-founder of XYO Network, who also said it’s better to focus on trends within the crypto industry that offer sustainable value for the longer term.

“There are so many flash-in-the-pan pumps that focusing on any one coin could be dangerous for investors,” he said, “especially those who are new to the industry.”

With this in mind, infrastructure projects that aim to solve real problems are a good start, he added.

“This includes, for example, oracle projects that serve as the key data feeds connecting blockchains with the rest of the world, as well as blockchains with other blockchains,” Trouw said. “Indeed, as blockchain networks continue to grow, they will increasingly need data for a wide variety of purposes.”

Trouw added that the blockchain networks themselves — Ethereum, Solana and Polygon, etc. — are all experiencing solid user growth and technical development.

“In turn, developers are increasingly attracted to them because they know that there’s growing user interest,” he said. “The more developers and the more users a chain has, the better the longer term will look. Overall, it’s hard not to be bullish on the space, but it behooves investors to do their research before getting exposure to any particular project.”

More From GOBankingRates

This article originally appeared on GOBankingRates.com: Solana, Other Altcoins and Crypto Trends To Watch in 2023

title: 8 Best Solana Wallets in 2024 - CoinCodex
content:
Cryptocurrency wallets are an essential tool for any crypto investor. A wallet will allow you to safely store your crypto and utilize it in decentralized applications such as NFT marketplaces.

In this article, we will be focusing on Solana, as we’ve compiled a list of the best Solana wallets that are available in 2024. All the wallets featured in this article are non-custodial. This means that the user has the responsibility to securely back up their private keys and protect them from unauthorized access.

The best Solana wallets in 2024

Now, let’s check out the best Solana wallets in 2024. We’ve tried to highlight a diverse range of wallets to provide options for all kinds of crypto enthusiasts. Whether you’re just a passive HODLer or an active participant on the blockchain, you’ll be able to find a Solana wallet that’s right for you.

1. Ledger Nano S Plus - Best hardware wallet for Solana

Ledger Nano S Plus is a hardware cryptocurrency wallet that provides secure private key storage and a wide range of supported cryptocurrencies. This of course also includes Solana, and the Ledger Nano S Plus is overall the best option for users that want to store their SOL securely.

Please note that the Ledger Nano S Plus and its associated Ledger Live software currently don’t offer direct support for SPL tokens issued on the Solana network, and only support SOL at the moment. However, you can connect your Ledger Nano S Plus to a wallet like Solflare and use it to manage your SPL tokens securely.

Buy a Ledger Nano S Plus

Why did we choose Ledger Nano S Plus?

The Ledger Nano S Plus is a very affordable device that will drastically improve the security of your crypto holdings. If you plan to hold SOL over the long term, a Solana hardware wallet like the Ledger Nano S Plus would be a very wise purchase. Ledger has been leading the hardware crypto wallet sector for several years now, and regularly releases updates to improve security.

The Ledger Nano S Plus is relatively easy and quick to set up, and the wallet’s Ledger Live software provides a convenient way to check the growth of your crypto portfolio and transact with your coins securely.

Ledger Nano S Plus pros: High level of security

Supports many other cryptocurrencies in addition to SOL

Affordable price Ledger Nano S Plus cons: Doesn’t natively support SPL standard tokens on Solana

User experience is slightly less convenient than software wallets

2. NGRAVE ZERO - Best Ledger alternative for SOL holders

The NGRAVE ZERO is a high-end hardware cryptocurrency wallet with advanced security features. In contrast to most other hardware crypto wallets, the NGRAVE ZERO has a large touchscreen which makes the user experience smoother. The large screen is also used to display QR codes used to sign transactions, as the device itself is completely air-gapped with no access to any connectivity, not even USB.

In addition, the NGRAVE ZERO has an operating system with the EAL7 security certification, and also features a biometric sensor for additional security.

Why did we choose NGRAVE ZERO?

The NGRAVE ZERO is a very secure option for storing SOL, and is worth considering for users who have a significant investment in Solana. When combined with a secure physical backup, the NGRAVE ZERO is one of the safest ways of storing Solana, short of using the services of professional cryptocurrency custody firms.

NGRAVE ZERO pros: Extremely high security

More user-friendly design than other hardware wallets

Supports a solid selection of cryptocurrencies NGRAVE ZERO cons: Relatively high price

Less convenient than a software wallet

Get the NGRAVE ZERO

3. Phantom - Best Solana software wallet overall

Phantom is the most popular wallet that was specifically designed for Solana (it’s currently being expanded to other blockchains as well). Phantom is available either as a mobile app on iOS and Android, or as a browser extension in Chrome, Firefox and other popular browsers.

Phantom provides native support for SOL, SPL tokens, as well as Solana-based non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The wallet also makes it convenient to earn additional SOL through staking.

The Phantom wallet also supports Ledger hardware wallets, so you can connect your Ledger device to phantom and securely transact with SOL and other Solana-based crypto assets.

Why did we choose Phantom?

Phantom was designed specifically for Solana, which is reflected in the wallet’s seamless user experience. Phantom provides a very convenient way to store and transact with Solana-based cryptocurrencies, and also makes it easy to access Solana’s ecosystem of decentralized applications. It also has a built-in token swapping functionality so users can trade between different Solana-based tokens directly from their wallet.

In addition, Phantom supports SOL staking, which is something that practically all long-term Solana investors will be interested in.

Phantom pros: A wallet designed for Solana

Available as a browser extension or mobile app

Seamless user experience

Support for Ledger hardware wallets Phantom cons: Currently only supports Solana

Less secure than hardware wallets

Get Phantom Wallet

4. Solflare - Best Solana wallet for safety

Similarly to Phantom, Solflare is also a wallet that was designed specifically for Solana. It offers the full suite of functionality one would expect from a Solana wallet, including support for SOL, SPL tokens and NFTs, SOL staking, and access to decentralized applications. So, if you’re looking to trade on Solana NFT marketplaces, Solflare is a solid option for you.

Solflare implements unique security features, which can help users from falling victim to phishing or signing malicious transactions. Another unique aspect of Solflare is that users have access to direct customer support, which is very rare among non-custodial cryptocurrency wallets.

Solflare is available as a browser extension for Chrome, or as a mobile app for both iOS and Android.

Why did we choose Solflare?

The most impressive aspect of Solflare is the wallet’s security features. For example, Solflare will alert users when they’re accessing a website that has been tagged as potentially malicious.

The wallet also offers a transaction simulation feature, which tells the user what will happen after the transaction is executed. This helps protect users from interacting with malicious contracts that are designed to steal funds.

Beyond the security features, Solflare is also just a solid all-purpose SOL wallet that provides practically all the features one would expect.

Solflare pros: Useful security features

Available as a browser extension or mobile app

Support for Ledger hardware wallets Solflare cons: Only supports Solana-based crypto assets

Less secure than hardware wallets

Get Solflare Wallet

5. Trust Wallet - Best Solana wallet with multi-currency support

Trust Wallet is a cryptocurrency wallet that supports a very large number of cryptocurrencies, including Solana. Overall, the Trust Wallet app supports coins and token across 65 different blockchain platforms. The wallet can of course also be used to store NFTs.

Trust Wallet was initially launched as a mobile app, but is now also available as a browser extension. In addition to the core wallet functionality, Trust Wallet also gives users access to a range of services, including credit card crypto purchases, token swaps, a DApp browser, and more.

Why did we choose Trust Wallet?

Trust Wallet is one of the popular cryptocurrency wallets on the market, and has a solid track record. It also packs more features than most other crypto wallets, as it can also be used to swap between tokens or buy cryptocurrency with a credit or debit card.

Overall, Trust Wallet is the best choice for users that hold many different cryptocurrencies and want to manage them in one place instead of using multiple wallets. If you also hold other cryptocurrencies in addition to Solana, Trust Wallet is definitely worth checking out.

Trust Wallet pros: Supports many different cryptocurrencies

Offers credit and debit card purchases

Ledger hardware wallet support Trust Wallet cons: Less secure than hardware wallets

Not designed specifically for Solana

Get Trust Wallet

6. XDEFI Wallet - Best Solana wallet for DeFi fans

XDEFI Wallet is a strong option for users that hold many different cryptocurrencies, as it supports over 15 different blockchain platforms. The XDEFI Wallet is designed for DeFi enthusiasts and NFT collectors, but it can of course also be used to simply store SOL.

Notably, XDEFI Wallet features cross-chain token swapping functionality, making it easy for users to swap between different coins and tokens directly from their wallet.

However, it’s worth keeping in mind that XDEFI wallet is currently only available as a browser extension. So, if you’re primarily using your mobile device to transact with crypto, consider other options.

Why did we choose XDEFI Wallet?

XDEFI Wallet is a great choice for users that hold many different cryptocurrencies, and provides a smooth user experience. It’s implemented as a browser extension, which is already a familiar experience for many cryptocurrency users.

7. Squads - Best Solana multisig wallet

Squads is a unique multisignature wallet for Solana. A multisignature wallet requires multiple signatures for a transaction to be approved. This is useful for use cases like treasuries and DAOs, where approval from multiple parties is required before funds can be spent. Squads supports token swaps, SOL staking, batch payments, and other useful features.

Why did we choose Squads?

While Squads isn’t designed for regular Solana users, we think it’s still worth highlighting because it offers advanced features that can’t be found in most other wallets. The Squads wallet can be a great option for development teams, DAOs and others building on the Solana blockchain.

The Squads smart contract has been formally verified and completed multiple independent audits. In addition, Squads was written with the Anchor development framework, which helps developers create more secure Solana programs.

Great for DAOs and other teams

8. Coinbase Wallet – Best Solana wallet for Coinbase users

Coinbase Wallet is a non-custodial cryptocurrency wallet developed by the Coinbase exchange. The wallet is highly versatile, supporting multiple blockchains such as Solana, Bitcoin, Ethereum, XRP, Stellar, Litecoin, and Dogecoin. Additionally, it supports the storage and management of various SPL tokens on the Solana blockchain. Please note that Solana and SPL tokens are currently only supported on the browser extension version of Coinbase Wallet.

Coinbase Wallet goes beyond basic functionality by incorporating advanced features. For example, users can execute token swaps directly within the wallet’s interface through decentralized exchanges. The wallet also supports non-fungible tokens (NFTs), catering to the growing interest in digital collectibles.

Why did we choose Coinbase Wallet?

For users who already use Coinbase as their primary exchange, the Coinbase Wallet offers added convenience. It can be linked directly to a Coinbase account, enabling seamless transfers between the wallet and the exchange. This integration makes Coinbase Wallet an excellent choice for those looking to manage a wide range of digital assets within the Coinbase ecosystem.

​​​In the list above, we featured both software Solana wallets and hardware Solana wallets. Let’s quickly explain the difference between these two types of wallets.

Software Solana wallets

Software Solana wallets include browser extension wallets, mobile wallets and desktop wallets. These are “hot wallets”, since the private keys are stored on a device that’s connected to the internet. Hot wallets are convenient to use, but come with more security risks as they are vulnerable to online attacks.

Hardware Solana wallets

Hardware cryptocurrency wallets are devices that securely store the private keys necessary for transacting with cryptocurrencies. These are “cold wallets”, as the devices are not connected to the internet. Even though you have to connect your hardware wallet to your computer or mobile phone to make transactions, the hardware wallet only signs transactions, but doesn’t disclose the private keys to the connected device.

However, there are also downsides to hardware wallets. You have to buy a physical device, and they’re also less convenient to use than software wallets.

The bottom line—What’s the best wallet for Solana?

If you’re investing in Solana and need a wallet, there’s a wealth of options for you to explore. In this article, we have featured 7 high-quality Solana wallets for all kinds of cryptocurrency users.

The choice of the best Solana wallet for you will depend on various factors. For example, if you just need a wallet for Solana, you can’t go wrong with Phantom or Solflare. On the other hand, a wallet like Trust Wallet will serve you better if you want to hold other cryptocurrencies as well. For users that put a lot of value on security, it’s definitely worth considering hardware Solana wallets like the Ledger Nano S Plus.

Setting up a cryptocurrency wallet, be it a software or a hardware one, is one of the most important steps you can take to make your crypto investing journey safe and secure. For additional tips, check out our ultimate guide on how to invest in crypto.
